Hunger and Undernourishment

Max Roser [cite]
OWID presents work from many different people and organizations. When citing this entry, please also cite the original data source. This entry can be cited as:

Max Roser (2016) – ‘Hunger and Undernourishment’. Published online at OurWorldInData.org. Retrieved from: https://ourworldindata.org/hunger-and-undernourishment/ [Online Resource]

# Undernourishment before 1990

We do not have much quantitative information on malnourishment before 1990.

In 2006 the FAO stated the following prevalence of undernourishment in the developing world:
1969-71: 37%    1979-81: 28%    1990-92: 20%    2001-03:17%11
The numbers for 1990 have since been corrected upwards but the FAO has not (to my knowledge) published new estimates for the time before 1990. For the correction see below.

 

The following map shows the hunger levels in Europe at the end of World War I

# Hunger map of Europe, May 1919 – The New York Times12

# Correlates, Determinants & Consequences

# Correlation matrix of key food security indicators in all developing regions – FAO (2013)13

# Poverty vs. prevalence of undernourishment – FAO (2013)14

# Millennium Development Goal (MDG) 1 target achievement trajectories and actual progress on key indicators (poverty, undernourishment, underweight) for all developing regions, since 1990 – FAO (2013)15

# Undernourishment by Family Income and Parents Education

# Stunting among children under 5 years of age by household wealth quintile in Mozambique, 1999-2003 – WHO (2007)16

# Severe stunting among children under 3 by mother’s level of education for selected countries, most recent year – UNESCO (2009)17

 

# Data Quality & Definition

Here I present the definitions used by the FAO.18 I have specified when I have used a different definition above.

  • Malnutrition is defined as an ‘abnormal physiological condition caused by inadequate, unbalanced or excessive consumption of macronutrients and/or micronutrients. Malnutrition includes undernutrition and overnutrition
    as well as micronutrient deficiencies.’

    • Overnourishment is defined as ‘food intake that is continuously in excess of dietary energy requirements’.
    • Undernourishment is ‘a state, lasting for at least one year, of inability to acquire enough food, defined as a level of food intake insufficient to meet dietary energy requirements’.

In the FAO report ‘hunger’ is synonymous with ‘chronic undernourishment’.

Consequences of Undernourishment

The consequence of undernourishment is called Undernutrition. And the FAO names four outcomes of undernourishment, and/or poor absorption and/or poor biological use of nutrients consumed as a result of repeated infectious disease.

These are:

  • Being underweight for one’s age.
    • Underweight is defined as ‘low weight for age in children, and BMI of less than 18.5 in adults’.19
  • For children, two consequences of undernourishment are:
    • being ‘too short for one’s age’ which is called stunting,
    • being ‘dangerously thin for one’s height’  which is called wasting,
  • and being ‘deficient in vitamins and minerals’ which is called ‘micronutrient malnutrition‘.
# Estimates of undernourished people in the world, 1990-2012 – FAO 2010 and 2012 report compared – Max Roser20

 

# Data Sources

 

# FAO Food Security Indicator
  • Data: Many indicators – the full list is here.
  • Geographical coverage: Global – by country and world region (some indicators are only available for developing countries).
  • Time span: Since 1990.
  • Available at: Available for download here.
  •  The whole dataset can be downloaded in one xls file.
# WHO – Global Health Observatory (GHO)
  • Data: Underweight children
  • Geographical coverage: Global – by country and region.
  • Time span: Since 1990 – with projections to 2025.
  • Available at: Online here.
  •  This data is presented in the context of the Millenium Development Goals (MDG). The UN’s MDG website also presents data.
# International Food Policy Research Institute (IFPRI)
  • Data: Global Hunger Index and single dimensions (Prevalence of undernourishment in the population, prevalence of underweight in children under five years, under-five mortality rate)
  • Geographical coverage:  Global – by country.
  • Time span: Since 1990.
  • Available at: Online here.
  •  The Global Hunger Index is a multidimensional measure of hunger. It was first published by the ‘Welthungerhilfe’ but is now published by IFPR. Here is the Wikipedia entry.
# World Bank – World Development Indicators
  • Geographical coverage: Global – by country.
  • Time span: Since 1960 but not annual and for some countries very scattered.
  • Available at: Some of the data that are available:
    • Malnutrition prevalence, weight for age (% of children under 5) (also available for males and females separately) Data available from the 60s onwards – very scattered before 1980 and also not annual for the time after. Varying by country.
    • Malnutrition prevalence, height for age (% of children under 5) (also available for males and females separately) Data available from the 60s onwards – very scattered before 1980 and also not annual for the time after. Varying by country.
    • Prevalence of wasting (% of children under 5) – Data available from the 60s onwards – very scattered before 1980 and also not annual for the time after. Varying by country.
    • Low-birthweight babies (% of births) – Data available from 1990 onwards – very scattered. Varying by country.
    • Prevalence of undernourishment (% of population) – Annual data available from 1990 onwards.

 

# Regular Important Publications

A regular FAO report is the The State of Food Insecurity in the World report.

 

Footnotes

  1. This data is taken from International Food Policy Research Institute (IFPRI). The numbers are underlying their Global Hunger Index calculations 1990, 1995, 2000, 2005, and 2013.
    The data is available for download here.

    The map shows the ‘Prevalence of undernourishment in the population (%)’. The original data source is the FAO and some data are estimates by IFPRI.

  2. I have taken these data from the Food Security Indicators of the FAO that are available for download here.
    The data presented here was last updated by the FAO on 16 September, 2014.

    Values are plotted at midpoint of 3-year-periods for which averages are given (1991 here refers to the three-year average of the period 1990-92 etc.).
    According to the same source the prevalence of undernourishment in ‘developed regions’ was below 5% for the entire period. More specific data is not presented for the ‘developed regions’.

  3. I have taken these data from the Food Security Indicators of the FAO that are available for download here.
    The data presented here was last updated by the FAO on 16 September 2014.

    Values are plotted at midpoint of 3-year-periods for which averages are given (1991 here refers to the three-year average of the period 1990-92 etc.).

  4. The map shows the prevalence of undernourishment in the total population as of 2010 – 2012. The indicator is an estimate of the percentage of the population having access to an amount of energy from food insufficient to maintain a healthy life.

    An interactive version of this map is available at the website of the WFP here.
    As a pdf it can be downloaded here.

    The source on which this map is based is FAO, IFAD and WFP (2012) – The State of Food Insecurity in the World 2012: Economic growth is necessary but not sufficient to accelerate reduction of hunger and malnutrition. Rome. Online here.

  5. The source is the publication World Bank (2013) – World Development Indicators
    2013. Washington, DC: World Bank. Online here.
    Licensed by the source: Creative Commons Attribution CC BY 3.0

  6. This data is taken from the Food Security Indicators of the FAO that are available for download here.
    The data presented here was last updated by the FAO on October 1st, 2013.
    The FAO-source does not publish data on regional aggregates and the country specific data is scattered (gaps in the data & not available for some countries).

    The original data source given by the FAO is the World Bank series on Malnutrition prevalence, weight for age (% of children under 5). It is online here.

    The data is scattered. I have chosen 13 countries for which more data is available and that are from different world regions.

    In the source Laos is called Lao People’s Democratic Republic, Bolivia is called Bolivia (Plurinational State of) and Iran is called Iran (Islamic Republic of).

  7. The source of this map is Center for International Earth Science Information Network (CIESIN), Columbia University of the City of New York. It is online at SEDAC (NASA) here.

    Children are defined as underweight if their weight-for-age z-scores are more than two standard deviations below the median of the NCHS/CDC/WHO International Reference Population.

    The document is licensed by SEDAC under a Creative Commons 2.5 Attributions License.

  8. The source is UNESCO (2012) EFA Global Monitoring Report – Youth and Skills Putting education to work

    The report is online here.

  9. This data is taken from the Food Security Indicators of the FAO that are available for download here.
    The data presented here was last updated by the FAO on October 1st, 2013.
    The FAO-source does not publish data on regional aggregates and the country specific data is scattered (gaps in the data & not available for some countries).

    The original data source given by the FAO is the World Bank series on Malnutrition prevalence, height for age (% of children under 5). It is online here.

    The data is scattered. I have chosen 11 countries from different world regions for which more data are available.

  10. The source is the FAO (2013) – Statistical Yearbook, online here.

  11. Food and Agriculture Organization Agricultural and Development Economics Division. “The State of Food Insecurity in the World, 2006 : Eradicating world hunger – taking stock ten years after the World Food Summit”. Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations, 2006, p. 8.
    http://www.fao.org/docrep/009/a0750e/a0750e00.htm

    The original quote is “… a reduction in the proportion of undernourished people in the developing countries by 3 percentage points – from 20 percent in 1990–92 to 17 percent in 2001–03. … However, progress over this period was slower than over the previous two decades, when the prevalence of undernourishment declined by 9 percent (from 37 percent to 28 percent) between 1969–71 and 1979–81 and by a further 8 percentage points (to 20 percent) between 1979–81 and 1990–92.

     

    Similar numbers – including estimates of the total number of undernourished people – were published in the 2010 report.

  12. This is a map in an article published first in the newspaper The New York Times Current History Magazine for the April-May-June 1919 (Volume X, p. 52). My source is Wikipedia here.

  13. The source is FAO, IFAD & WFP (2013) – The State of Food Insecurity in the World 2013 – The multiple dimensions of food security, Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO), the International Fund for Agricultural Development (IFAD) or of the World Food Programme (WFP), FAO, Rome, 2013. Online here.

    The FAO is the source and copyright holder of this material.

  14. The source is FAO, IFAD & WFP (2013) – The State of Food Insecurity in the World 2013 – The multiple dimensions of food security, Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO), the International Fund for Agricultural Development (IFAD) or of the World Food Programme (WFP), FAO, Rome, 2013. Online here.

    The FAO is the source and copyright holder of this material.

    The y-axis shows the ‘poverty headcount ratio at $1.25/day’.

  15. The source is FAO, IFAD & WFP (2013) – The State of Food Insecurity in the World 2013 – The multiple dimensions of food security, Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO), the International Fund for Agricultural Development (IFAD) or of the World Food Programme (WFP), FAO, Rome, 2013. Online here.

    The FAO is the source and copyright holder of this material.

  16. The source is WHO (2007) – World Health Statistics – 2007. World Health Organization. Online here.

    Note by the source: Household wealth index constructed using durable goods, type of materials used in housing floor and number of rooms divided by the number of household members. Wealth quintile 1 indicates the poorest and wealth quintile 5, the least poor.

  17. The source is UNESCO (2009) EFA Global Monitoring Report – Overcoming inequality: why governance matters.

    The report is online here.
    Severe stunting here is defined as a height-for-age score below minus 3 standard deviations from the reference median.
    The source of my source is Macro International Inc. (2008).

  18. Specifically FAO, IFAD & WFP (2013) – The State of Food Insecurity in the World 2013 – The multiple dimensions of food security, Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO), the International Fund for Agricultural Development (IFAD) or of the World Food Programme (WFP), FAO, Rome, 2013. Online here.

  19. The body mass index (BMI) is ‘the ratio of weight-for-height measured as the weight in kilograms divided by the square of height in metres’.

  20. My numbers are taken from The Economist here.
    The original sources are the

    FAO, IFAD & WFP (2010) – The State of Food Insecurity in the World 2013 – Addressing food insecurity in protracted crises, Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO), the International Fund for Agricultural Development (IFAD) or of the World Food Programme (WFP), FAO, Rome, 2013. Online here.
    and

Our World in Data

Our World in Data is an online publication by Max Roser which explores the development of human living conditions at a global scale. Our work is licensed under CC BY-SA and freely usable by everyone (including journalists, authors, bloggers, lecturers, or educators).
